metadata.description: Persian words that have no direct equivalent in other languages. Requires special translation strategies.

emotional_concepts.description: Words expressing emotions unique to Persian culture

دلتنگی.why_untranslatable: Combines homesickness, longing, sadness, and a physical sensation of heart tightness. No single English word captures all nuances.
دلتنگی.usage_context: Used when deeply missing a person, place, or time
دلتنگی.example: دلم برایت تنگ شده (I miss you deeply - literally: my heart has become tight for you)

غم.why_untranslatable: A profound, philosophical sadness often seen as beautiful and poetic in Persian culture, unlike Western sadness which is purely negative.
غم.usage_context: Common in poetry, often valued as a sign of depth
غم.example: غم عالم را می‌خورم (I consume the world's sorrow)
translation_strategies: Consider cultural note about Persian valuation of غم

طرب.why_untranslatable: Specifically the emotional state induced by music and poetry - a spiritual/aesthetic ecstasy unique to Persian/Arabic culture.
طرب.usage_context: Classical music, poetry gatherings, Sufi contexts

social_concepts.description: Words describing social dynamics unique to Persian culture

تعارف.why_untranslatable: A complex system of ritualized politeness involving insincere offers, refusals, and deference. No equivalent in Western cultures.
تعارف.example: تعارف نکن (Don't do ta'arof - i.e., be honest)
translation_strategies: Explain the specific behavior being described

آبرو.why_untranslatable: Combines personal honor, family reputation, social standing, and dignity. Loss of آبرو is catastrophic in Iranian society.
translation_strategies: 'Face' in social contexts (like Chinese 面子)

مروت.why_untranslatable: A complex virtue combining generosity, helping the weak, keeping promises, and noble behavior. Rooted in pre-Islamic Persian values.

رودربایستی.why_untranslatable: The feeling of being unable to say no or express true feelings due to social propriety. Related to but distinct from ta'arof.
رودربایستی.usage_context: When someone can't refuse due to social pressure
رودربایستی.example: رودربایستی نکن (Don't be inhibited - be honest)

غیرت.why_untranslatable: A complex concept of protective honor, especially regarding family/women. Can be positive (protectiveness) or negative (controlling).

spiritual_concepts.description: Words from Persian mysticism and spirituality

عشق.why_untranslatable: In Persian, عشق is far more intense than English 'love'. It implies consuming passion, often with spiritual/mystical dimensions. Distinct from محبت (affection).
عشق.example: عشق آمد و شد خون دلم (Love came and became the blood of my heart)

حال.why_untranslatable: In Sufi context, refers to a transient spiritual state. In everyday use, means mood/condition. The word covers vast semantic range.
حال.example: حالم خوب است (I'm fine) vs حال عرفانی (mystical state)

فنا.why_untranslatable: Sufi concept of the annihilation of the ego in divine presence. Technical religious term with no Western equivalent.

daily_life_concepts.description: Everyday concepts unique to Persian/Iranian life

کیف.why_untranslatable: A specific pleasant feeling, especially from relaxation, good company, or mild indulgence. Borrowed by many languages (kaif, kef).
کیف.example: کیف می‌کنم (I'm enjoying/having a good time)

مزه.why_untranslatable: Means both literal taste AND enjoyment/fun. A person can be 'با مزه' (tasty/fun/amusing).
مزه.example: این آدم بامزه‌ای است (This person is funny/amusing)

صفا.why_untranslatable: Combines purity, sincerity, and the pleasure of good company. Used in phrases like 'صفا کردیم' (we had a good sincere time).
صفا.example: صفا کردیم (We had a wonderful time)

دم.why_untranslatable: Means breath, but also someone's presence/company/energy. 'دمت گرم' (may your breath be warm) = thank you/you're awesome.

general_approaches.when_to_use: When the concept is central to the text
general_approaches.example: ta'arof (the Persian system of ritual politeness)

general_approaches.when_to_use: When flow matters but meaning is important
general_approaches.example: honor* (*آبرو encompasses reputation, dignity, and social standing)
the aching longing of missing someone deeply

general_approaches.when_to_use: When equivalent exists in target culture
general_approaches.example: face (like Chinese 面子) for آبرو

translation_strategies.warning: Never force a single-word translation when the concept is complex
